nodes.title: Table 2: Enhancement of 6Li Amount in Each Component after ...
nodes.text:
electrolyte is 0.05 ppm, whereas it increases to 0.07 and 0.18
ppm in LLZO (20 wt %) −PEO (LiTFSI) and LLZO (50 wt
%)−PEO (LiTFSI), respectively ( Table S1 ). It has been
established that the addition of ceramic ﬁllers can reduce
polymer crystallization,22which in turn increases the disorder
of Li-ion local environments within polymers, manifested asbroadened LiTFSI resonances in
6Li NMR. A minor reduction
in the FWHM of the LiTFSI resonance from 0.18 to 0.15 is
seen with the addition TEGDME to the LLZO −PEO (LiTFSI)
composite. It is expected that liquid TEGDME will enhance Li-ion motion, which partially averages out the environmental
anisotropy and thus reduces the NMR line width.
To probe the Li-ion mobility in the composite electrolytes,
the
7LiT1relaxation times are measured for the LiTFSI and
LLZO associated phases. The results are shown in Table 1 .
With the increase of the LLZO fraction in the composite, the
7LiT1relaxation times increase for Li in LiTFSI, which suggests
a slowdown of Li-ion motion. The possible reasons are: (i)
LLZO particles make the composite rigid, which limits the
motion of Li ions within the matrix; and (ii) big LLZO particles
are blocking Li-ion transport channels within the polymer. Bothfactors will result in reduced ion conduction within the polymerphase. The T
1relaxation times for LLZO-related phases,
including LLZO, LLZO −PEO interface, and decomposed
LLZO, increase with larger LLZO content. The T1for bulk
c-LLZO at room temperature is ∼1 s, which is not expected to
change signi ﬁcantly with increase in LLZO amount in the
composite. It also has been determined in our prior studies thatLi at the LLZO −PEO interface shares the same T
1∼1 s as Li
in bulk LLZO.32The variation in T1in the LLZO-related
phases is mainly from the contribution of the decomposed
LLZO phase, which exhibits very long T1in the LLZO −PEO
(LiTFSI) composites, that is, 10 −20 s ( Table 1 ). The7LiT1of
decomposed LLZO in LLZO (50 wt %) −PEO (LiTFSI) (50
wt %)−TEGDME is reduced compared to that in LLZO (50
wt %) −PEO (LiTFSI), suggesting increased Li motion in
TEGDME. The results show that Li-ion mobility decreaseswith increasing LLZO content in the composite, and small
molecule additives such as TEGDME render Li ions in the
composite more mobile.
To investigate Li-ion transport pathways within the
composite electrolytes, symmetric cells,
6Li metal |composite
electrolyte |6Li metal, were fabricated. These symmetric cells
were electrochemically cycled with a current density of 7.2 μA/
cm2, and the direction of the current was switched every 5 min.
The natural abundance of the6Li isotope is only 7.6%, which is
low compared to that of 92.4% for7Li. The slightly biased
potential induced by the electric current drives6Li ions from
one6Li-enriched metal electrode to pass through the composite
electrolyte and reach the other6Li-enriched metal electrode.
During this process,6Li ions partially replace7Li ions in the
composite electrolytes. Therefore, the components comprisingLi-ion transport pathways will be preferentially
6Li-enriched
with repeated electrochemical cycling. Quantitative evaluationof the change in6Li amount for each component within the
composite electrolyte will reveal the preferred pathways for Li-ion transport.
The
6Li NMR spectra of pristine composite electrolytes and
those after6Li→7Li replacement are shown in Figure 2 . The
quanti ﬁcation of6Li enrichment based on spectral area integrals
is documented in Table 2 . For the LLZO (5 wt %) −PEO
(LiTFSI) composite,6Li enrichment of 23.3% is observed for
LiTFSI in PEO, suggesting that Li ions pass through the PEO
matrix for conduction. In addition to the intensity increase(Figure 2 a), the
6Li resonance also shifts to the right, an
indication of change in Li-ion local environments. Li ions
associated with crystalline PEO often exhibit a6Li resonance at
∼0.3 ppm, and the resonance tends to shift to lower ppm for Li
in amorphous PEO due to reduced PEO −Li interactions.32
Therefore, the shift of the resonance after6Li→7Li
replacement is a manifestation of weakened Li −PEO
interaction; this often facilitates Li-ion conduction.
With the increase in LLZO content to 20 wt % in the
composite, that is, LLZO (20 wt %) −PEO (LiTFSI), the6Li
signals from LLZO, PEO −LLZO interface, decomposed
LLZO, and LiTFSI can be distinctively observed. After the
6Li→7Li replacement operation, LLZO and interface
resonances do not show any notable changes, whereas the6Li
amount in decomposed LLZO and LiTFSI increased by 10.6
and 21.2%, respectively. The preferred6Li enrichment of
decomposed LLZO and LiTFSI implies that Li-ion conductionoccurs via Li salts in PEO. Li salts are partially from LiTFSI
dispersed in PEO and partially from decomposed LLZO. The
ball-milling mixing breaks bulk LLZO into small granules, andthese decomposed LLZO particles are distributed within PEO.The extraordinarily large T
1(>10 s) of decomposed LLZO
compared to that ( ∼1 s) of other Li-containing components in
the composite electrolytes suggests that decomposed LLZO is
spatially in a separate phase. The lack of1H−6Li cross-
polarization signal for decomposed LLZO infers very weakinteractions between decomposed LLZO and the PEO matrix
(Figure S4 ). The low strength of the interaction again favors
fast Li-ion conduction. The lack of bulk LLZO participation inLi conduction in LLZO (20 wt %) −PEO (LiTFSI) composite
is likely due to the low LLZO content, which does not allow the
formation of a percolated network for Li to pass through. In
summary, LLZO (20 wt %) −PEO (LiTFSI) is still a polymer
electrolyte modi ﬁed by LLZO as ﬁllers, and its decomposed
form serves as an additional Li source.
For LLZO (50 wt %) −PEO (LiTFSI) ( Figure 2 c), after
6Li
→7Li replacement, the6Li peak of bulk LLZO at 2.3 ppm is
increased signi ﬁcantly by 27.2%. In addition, the PEO −LLZO
interface and LiTFSI resonances show small6Li enrichment,
6.3 and 8.7%, respectively. No6Li enrichment is observed for
the resonance from decomposed LLZO. Therefore, themajority of Li ions pass through the percolated networkformed by LLZO particles and a small portion transport via
LiTFSI in PEO. Decomposed LLZO plays a minor role in Li-Table 2. Enhancement of6Li Amount in Each Component after Cycling for LLZO (5 wt %) −PEO (LiTFSI), LLZO (20 wt %) −

nodes.summary:
The partial document describes an investigation into Li-ion transport and mobility in LLZO-PEO (LiTFSI) composite electrolytes, examining the impact of LLZO ceramic filler concentration and the additive TEGDME.

Key points covered include:
*   **Effect of Fillers and Additives on Li-ion Environment:** Ceramic fillers (LLZO) reduce polymer crystallization and increase disorder in Li-ion local environments, while TEGDME enhances Li-ion motion and reduces NMR linewidths.
*   **Li-ion Mobility (7Li T1 Relaxation):** Increasing LLZO content generally slows down Li-ion motion in both LiTFSI and LLZO-related phases, attributed to increased composite rigidity and blocked transport channels. Conversely, TEGDME is shown to increase Li-ion mobility. A distinct "decomposed LLZO" phase with very long T1 relaxation times is identified.
*   **Li-ion Transport Pathways (6Li NMR Spectroscopy):**
    *   At low LLZO content (5 wt%), Li-ion conduction primarily occurs through the PEO matrix via LiTFSI.
    *   At intermediate LLZO content (20 wt%), conduction is mainly via Li salts in PEO, including both LiTFSI and a "decomposed LLZO" phase, which acts as an additional Li source and facilitates fast conduction. Bulk LLZO does not form a percolated network.
    *   At high LLZO content (50 wt%), the majority of Li ions transport through a percolated network formed by the LLZO particles, with a smaller contribution from LiTFSI in PEO.
    *   The addition of TEGDME to the 50 wt% LLZO composite influences transport pathways, reducing bulk LLZO participation and increasing the role of decomposed LLZO and LiTFSI.

In essence, the document details how LLZO concentration dictates the dominant Li-ion transport mechanism (polymer-based vs. ceramic network) and how small molecule additives like TEGDME can significantly enhance Li-ion mobility and modify transport pathways within these composite electrolytes.

nodes.summary: This partial document details the mechanisms of Li-ion transport and factors influencing ionic conductivity in LLZO-PEO composite electrolytes. It highlights that the type of Li salt significantly impacts conductivity, with LiTFSI leading to higher performance due to easier dissociation and more free Li ions compared to LiClO4. The addition of a plasticizer like TEGDME is shown to alter Li-ion pathways, shifting dominant transport from LLZO to the Li salts within the modified PEO matrix, while also enhancing conductivity by reducing PEO crystallization. The document further explains how varying LLZO content dictates the primary transport pathway, transitioning from a polymer-dominated electrolyte at low LLZO to a ceramic-dominated one at higher concentrations, where LLZO forms a percolated network. However, high LLZO content can also impede ion mobility and block polymer pathways. Finally, it summarizes the complex effects of increasing LLZO on ionic conductivity, involving changes in ion mobility, transport pathways, and the concentration of active Li ions.

metadata.original_title: Investigation of Li-ion Transport Pathways via Isotope Replacement

nodes.title: Comparison of LiTFSI and LiClO4 in LLZO-PEO Composites
nodes.text:
ion conduction in LLZO (50 wt %) −PEO (LiTFSI), which is
likely due to relatively high activation energies for Li-ion
transport compared with other pathways. It is worth noting thatin our previous study on LLZO (50 wt %) −PEO (LiClO
4)
composite electrolyte, almost all Li ions transport throughLLZO and few of them through LiClO
4in PEO.30The
diﬀerence of Li-ion transport pathways in LLZO (50 wt %) −
PEO (LiTFSI) and LLZO (50 wt %) −PEO (LiClO4)i s
precisely from the type of Li salts. In general, Li salts withbulkier anions exhibit higher ionic conductivity. For instance,the conductivity of PEO −LiClO
4electrolytes is on the order of
10−7S/cm at room temperature, whereas that of PEO −LiTFSI
electrolytes is 10−5S/cm. LiTFSI with larger anions can
dissociate in the PEO matrix more easily and release more freeLi ions than LiClO
4, resulting in signi ﬁcant conductivity
enhancement. It is reported that, under similar stoichiometric
Li concentrations, the measured free Li-ion concentration from
LiTFSI in polymers is ∼3.4 times more than that from LiClO4,
which contributes to the observed much higher Li di ﬀusivity of
LiTFSI in polymers, ∼5.3 times more than that of LiClO 4.33
From this perspective, it is not hard to understand that LiTFSI
in PEO also makes measurable contribution to Li-ion
transportation in the LLZO (50 wt %) −PEO (LiTFSI)
composite electrolyte.
To further explore the in ﬂuence of chemical environments
on Li-ion pathways, a typical plasticizer, TEGDME, was addedinto LLZO −PEO (LiTFSI) during composite preparation.
TEGDME has been used as a non ﬂammable liquid electrolyte
for LIBs, and Li ionic conductivity of TEGDME is 10
−3S/cm
at room temperature. TEGDME can also reduce PEO
crystallization and increase the fraction of amorphous PEOphase, which is believed to account for fast Li-ion transport inPEO−TEGDME composites. It is seen in Figure 2 d that the
addition of TEGDME has altered Li-ion pathways compared
with composites without TEGDME. Bulk LLZO is not the
dominant component for Li-ion transportation anymore,showing only 7.0%
6Li enrichment. The integrals of6Li
resonances from decomposed LLZO and LiTFSI are increasedby 14.8 and 14.0%, respectively. These results indicate that Li
ions transport mainly through Li salts within the PEO −
TEGDME matrix.
The schematic of Li-ion pathways within LLZO −PEO
(LiTFSI) composite electrolytes of di ﬀerent LLZO contents
is shown in Figure 3 . To summarize, with low LLZO content
(<20 wt %), LLZO −PEO (LiTFSI) composites behave as a
polymer electrolyte modi ﬁed by LLZO. On increasing LLZO
amount to a critical point, LLZO particles connect to form apercolated network; thus, LLZO −PEO (LiTFSI) compositesfunction as a ceramic electrolyte. However, the ceramic
particles are diluted by polymers, and as a result, ceramic
electrolytes composed of loose particles exhibit much lowerionic conductivity compared with dense ceramic pellets.Moreover, bulk LLZO particles block Li-ion transport throughthe polymer matrix. Li transport pathways transition from the
PEO matrix to the percolated LLZO network when the LLZO
fraction in the composite electrolyte is increased to a criticalpoint. The exact transition point varies depending on manyfactors, including the particle size and morphology of LLZO aswell as the mixing degree of participating components. With
TEGDME additive, Li-ion conduction occurs mainly through
TEGDME-modi ﬁed polymer phase. The presence of
TEGDME additive in PEO has been shown to signi ﬁcantly
enhance Li-ion conduction.
34
The determination of Li-ion transport pathways also permits
the quanti ﬁcation of the relative concentration of active Li ions
for conduction. For LLZO (5 wt %) −PEO (LiTFSI), the active
Li ions are solely from LiTFSI. For LLZO (20 wt %) −PEO
(LiTFSI), an additional source of active Li ions is the
decomposed LLZO, which likely increases the charge carrierconcentration and thus improves the ionic conductivity.35For
LLZO (50 wt %) −PEO (LiTFSI), the main source of active Li
ions is bulk LLZO, with a minor contribution from LiTFSI. For
LLZO (50 wt %) −PEO (LiTFSI) (50 wt %) −TEGDME,
active Li ions are from LiTFSI, decomposed LLZO, and bulkLLZO. It is worth pointing out that although the nominalamount of active Li ions increases with increasing LLZOcontent, the actual fraction of Li ions participating in the
conduction may be reduced due to decreased ion mobility and
blockage of pathways in PEO by LLZO particles, which we willdiscuss next.
The e ﬀects of increasing LLZO content in the LLZO −PEO
(LiTFSI) composites on ionic conductivity channel through the
following three avenues: (i) ion mobility: the T
1relaxation time
measurements suggest that increasing LLZO contents decreaseion mobility; (ii) ion transport pathways:
6Li→7Li
replacement experiments reveal that at a critical LLZO content,
the composite will transition from a polymer electrolyte to a
ceramic electrolyte; and (iii) concentration of participating Liions in conduction: composites with <20 wt % LLZO show thatthe concentration of active Li ions rises with increasing LLZOcontent. With large LLZO content, on the one hand, the
number of Li ions originated from LLZO increases. On the
other hand, likely due to the blockage of Li conductionchannels by LLZO particles, the amount of active Li ions inPEO is reduced. As is seen, LLZO content can have totallyopposite e ﬀects on di ﬀerent parameters that determine ionic
Figure 3. Schematic of Li-ion pathways within LLZO (5 wt %) −PEO (LiTFSI), LLZO (20 wt %) −PEO (LiTFSI), LLZO (50 wt %) −PEO
(LiTFSI), and LLZO (50 wt %) −PEO (LiTFSI) (50 wt %) −TEGDME composite electrolytes.ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces Research Article
DOI: 10.1021/acsami.7b17301
ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces 2018, 10, 4113 −41204117
nodes.summary:
This partial document discusses the factors influencing Li-ion transport pathways and conductivity in LLZO-PEO composite electrolytes.

The main points covered are:

1.  **Effect of Li Salt Type:** It compares LiTFSI and LiClO4, showing that LiTFSI leads to significantly higher ionic conductivity and more Li-ion transport through the PEO matrix due to its bulkier anions, easier dissociation, and higher free Li-ion concentration and diffusivity.
2.  **Influence of Plasticizers:** The addition of TEGDME (a plasticizer) alters Li-ion pathways, shifting the primary transport mechanism from bulk LLZO to the Li salts within the PEO-TEGDME matrix. TEGDME also enhances conductivity by reducing PEO crystallization and increasing the amorphous phase.
3.  **Impact of LLZO Content:**
    *   At low LLZO content (<20 wt%), the composite behaves as a polymer electrolyte.
    *   As LLZO content increases to a critical point, LLZO particles form a percolated network, causing a transition to a ceramic-like electrolyte.
    *   High LLZO content can, however, lead to lower ionic conductivity compared to dense ceramics due to dilution by polymers and blockage of Li-ion transport through the polymer matrix.
    *   Li transport pathways transition from the PEO matrix to the percolated LLZO network with increasing LLZO fraction.
4.  **Sources of Active Li Ions:** The document details how the primary source of active Li ions for conduction varies with LLZO content, originating from LiTFSI, decomposed LLZO, and bulk LLZO in different proportions.
5.  **Overall Effects of Increasing LLZO Content:** It summarizes that increasing LLZO content impacts ion mobility (decreases), ion transport pathways (transitions from polymer to ceramic electrolyte), and the concentration of participating Li ions (increases at low LLZO but can be reduced in PEO at high LLZO due to blockage).

electrolytes is 10−5S/cm. LiTFSI with larger anions can

4, resulting in signi ﬁcant conductivity
enhancement. It is reported that, under similar stoichiometric
Li concentrations, the measured free Li-ion concentration from
LiTFSI in polymers is ∼3.4 times more than that from LiClO4,
which contributes to the observed much higher Li di ﬀusivity of
LiTFSI in polymers, ∼5.3 times more than that of LiClO 4.33
From this perspective, it is not hard to understand that LiTFSI
in PEO also makes measurable contribution to Li-ion
transportation in the LLZO (50 wt %) −PEO (LiTFSI)
composite electrolyte.
To further explore the in ﬂuence of chemical environments
on Li-ion pathways, a typical plasticizer, TEGDME, was addedinto LLZO −PEO (LiTFSI) during composite preparation.
TEGDME has been used as a non ﬂammable liquid electrolyte
for LIBs, and Li ionic conductivity of TEGDME is 10
−3S/cm
at room temperature. TEGDME can also reduce PEO
crystallization and increase the fraction of amorphous PEOphase, which is believed to account for fast Li-ion transport inPEO−TEGDME composites. It is seen in Figure 2 d that the
addition of TEGDME has altered Li-ion pathways compared
with composites without TEGDME. Bulk LLZO is not the
dominant component for Li-ion transportation anymore,showing only 7.0%
6Li enrichment. The integrals of6Li
resonances from decomposed LLZO and LiTFSI are increasedby 14.8 and 14.0%, respectively. These results indicate that Li
ions transport mainly through Li salts within the PEO −
TEGDME matrix.
The schematic of Li-ion pathways within LLZO −PEO
(LiTFSI) composite electrolytes of di ﬀerent LLZO contents
is shown in Figure 3 . To summarize, with low LLZO content
(<20 wt %), LLZO −PEO (LiTFSI) composites behave as a
polymer electrolyte modi ﬁed by LLZO. On increasing LLZO
amount to a critical point, LLZO particles connect to form apercolated network; thus, LLZO −PEO (LiTFSI) compositesfunction as a ceramic electrolyte. However, the ceramic
particles are diluted by polymers, and as a result, ceramic
electrolytes composed of loose particles exhibit much lowerionic conductivity compared with dense ceramic pellets.Moreover, bulk LLZO particles block Li-ion transport throughthe polymer matrix. Li transport pathways transition from the
PEO matrix to the percolated LLZO network when the LLZO
fraction in the composite electrolyte is increased to a criticalpoint. The exact transition point varies depending on manyfactors, including the particle size and morphology of LLZO aswell as the mixing degree of participating components. With
TEGDME additive, Li-ion conduction occurs mainly through
TEGDME-modi ﬁed polymer phase. The presence of
TEGDME additive in PEO has been shown to signi ﬁcantly
enhance Li-ion conduction.
34
The determination of Li-ion transport pathways also permits
the quanti ﬁcation of the relative concentration of active Li ions
for conduction. For LLZO (5 wt %) −PEO (LiTFSI), the active
Li ions are solely from LiTFSI. For LLZO (20 wt %) −PEO
(LiTFSI), an additional source of active Li ions is the
decomposed LLZO, which likely increases the charge carrierconcentration and thus improves the ionic conductivity.35For
LLZO (50 wt %) −PEO (LiTFSI), the main source of active Li
ions is bulk LLZO, with a minor contribution from LiTFSI. For
LLZO (50 wt %) −PEO (LiTFSI) (50 wt %) −TEGDME,
active Li ions are from LiTFSI, decomposed LLZO, and bulkLLZO. It is worth pointing out that although the nominalamount of active Li ions increases with increasing LLZOcontent, the actual fraction of Li ions participating in the
conduction may be reduced due to decreased ion mobility and
blockage of pathways in PEO by LLZO particles, which we willdiscuss next.
The e ﬀects of increasing LLZO content in the LLZO −PEO
(LiTFSI) composites on ionic conductivity channel through the
following three avenues: (i) ion mobility: the T
1relaxation time
measurements suggest that increasing LLZO contents decreaseion mobility; (ii) ion transport pathways:
6Li→7Li
replacement experiments reveal that at a critical LLZO content,
the composite will transition from a polymer electrolyte to a
ceramic electrolyte; and (iii) concentration of participating Liions in conduction: composites with <20 wt % LLZO show thatthe concentration of active Li ions rises with increasing LLZOcontent. With large LLZO content, on the one hand, the
number of Li ions originated from LLZO increases. On the
other hand, likely due to the blockage of Li conductionchannels by LLZO particles, the amount of active Li ions inPEO is reduced. As is seen, LLZO content can have totallyopposite e ﬀects on di ﬀerent parameters that determine ionic
Figure 3. Schematic of Li-ion pathways within LLZO (5 wt %) −PEO (LiTFSI), LLZO (20 wt %) −PEO (LiTFSI), LLZO (50 wt %) −PEO
(LiTFSI), and LLZO (50 wt %) −PEO (LiTFSI) (50 wt %) −TEGDME composite electrolytes.ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces Research Article
DOI: 10.1021/acsami.7b17301
ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces 2018, 10, 4113 −41204117
nodes.summary: This partial document details the mechanisms of Li-ion transport and factors influencing ionic conductivity in LLZO-PEO composite electrolytes. It highlights that the type of Li salt significantly impacts conductivity, with LiTFSI leading to higher performance due to easier dissociation and more free Li ions compared to LiClO4. The addition of a plasticizer like TEGDME is shown to alter Li-ion pathways, shifting dominant transport from LLZO to the Li salts within the modified PEO matrix, while also enhancing conductivity by reducing PEO crystallization. The document further explains how varying LLZO content dictates the primary transport pathway, transitioning from a polymer-dominated electrolyte at low LLZO to a ceramic-dominated one at higher concentrations, where LLZO forms a percolated network. However, high LLZO content can also impede ion mobility and block polymer pathways. Finally, it summarizes the complex effects of increasing LLZO on ionic conductivity, involving changes in ion mobility, transport pathways, and the concentration of active Li ions.

fraction in the composite electrolyte is increased to a criticalpoint. The exact transition point varies depending on manyfactors, including the particle size and morphology of LLZO aswell as the mixing degree of participating components. With
TEGDME additive, Li-ion conduction occurs mainly through
TEGDME-modi ﬁed polymer phase. The presence of
TEGDME additive in PEO has been shown to signi ﬁcantly
enhance Li-ion conduction.

the quanti ﬁcation of the relative concentration of active Li ions
for conduction. For LLZO (5 wt %) −PEO (LiTFSI), the active
Li ions are solely from LiTFSI. For LLZO (20 wt %) −PEO
(LiTFSI), an additional source of active Li ions is the
decomposed LLZO, which likely increases the charge carrierconcentration and thus improves the ionic conductivity.35For

ions is bulk LLZO, with a minor contribution from LiTFSI. For

active Li ions are from LiTFSI, decomposed LLZO, and bulkLLZO. It is worth pointing out that although the nominalamount of active Li ions increases with increasing LLZOcontent, the actual fraction of Li ions participating in the
conduction may be reduced due to decreased ion mobility and

nodes.summary:
This partial document discusses the factors influencing Li-ion transport pathways and conductivity in LLZO-PEO composite electrolytes.

The main points covered are:

1.  **Effect of Li Salt Type:** It compares LiTFSI and LiClO4, showing that LiTFSI leads to significantly higher ionic conductivity and more Li-ion transport through the PEO matrix due to its bulkier anions, easier dissociation, and higher free Li-ion concentration and diffusivity.
2.  **Influence of Plasticizers:** The addition of TEGDME (a plasticizer) alters Li-ion pathways, shifting the primary transport mechanism from bulk LLZO to the Li salts within the PEO-TEGDME matrix. TEGDME also enhances conductivity by reducing PEO crystallization and increasing the amorphous phase.
3.  **Impact of LLZO Content:**
    *   At low LLZO content (<20 wt%), the composite behaves as a polymer electrolyte.
    *   As LLZO content increases to a critical point, LLZO particles form a percolated network, causing a transition to a ceramic-like electrolyte.
    *   High LLZO content can, however, lead to lower ionic conductivity compared to dense ceramics due to dilution by polymers and blockage of Li-ion transport through the polymer matrix.
    *   Li transport pathways transition from the PEO matrix to the percolated LLZO network with increasing LLZO fraction.
4.  **Sources of Active Li Ions:** The document details how the primary source of active Li ions for conduction varies with LLZO content, originating from LiTFSI, decomposed LLZO, and bulk LLZO in different proportions.
5.  **Overall Effects of Increasing LLZO Content:** It summarizes that increasing LLZO content impacts ion mobility (decreases), ion transport pathways (transitions from polymer to ceramic electrolyte), and the concentration of participating Li ions (increases at low LLZO but can be reduced in PEO at high LLZO due to blockage).

nodes.summary: This partial document details the mechanisms of Li-ion transport and factors influencing ionic conductivity in LLZO-PEO composite electrolytes. It highlights that the type of Li salt significantly impacts conductivity, with LiTFSI leading to higher performance due to easier dissociation and more free Li ions compared to LiClO4. The addition of a plasticizer like TEGDME is shown to alter Li-ion pathways, shifting dominant transport from LLZO to the Li salts within the modified PEO matrix, while also enhancing conductivity by reducing PEO crystallization. The document further explains how varying LLZO content dictates the primary transport pathway, transitioning from a polymer-dominated electrolyte at low LLZO to a ceramic-dominated one at higher concentrations, where LLZO forms a percolated network. However, high LLZO content can also impede ion mobility and block polymer pathways. Finally, it summarizes the complex effects of increasing LLZO on ionic conductivity, involving changes in ion mobility, transport pathways, and the concentration of active Li ions.

nodes.title: Discussion of Ionic Conductivity and Stability
nodes.text: mobility, and active Li concentration on ionic conductivity aredetermined.
nodes.summary:
This partial document discusses the impact of varying concentrations of LLZO (lithium lanthanum zirconium oxide) and the addition of TEGDME (tetraethylene glycol dimethyl ether) on the ionic conductivity and stability of PEO (polyethylene oxide) composite electrolytes.

Key points covered include:
*   **Effect of LLZO concentration on ionic conductivity:**
    *   **Low LLZO (5 wt%)**: Acts as a filler, reducing PEO crystallinity but also blocking Li-ion pathways, leading to a slight reduction in conductivity.
    *   **Medium LLZO (20 wt%)**: Shows enhanced conductivity primarily due to additional Li ions released from decomposed LLZO, acting as a major charge carrier source.
    *   **High LLZO (50 wt%)**: Transforms the composite into an LLZO ceramic conductor with a percolated network, but also significantly blocks PEO pathways. This results in notably lower ionic conductivity due to the limited conduction through loosely connected LLZO particles.
*   **Role of TEGDME additive**: For high LLZO content (50 wt%), adding TEGDME significantly enhances ionic conductivity by increasing ion mobility, reducing PEO crystallinity, and re-establishing ion conduction channels within the PEO-TEGDME complex.
*   **Methodology and insights**: The study uses EIS (electrochemical impedance spectroscopy) to measure conductivity and solid-state NMR (nuclear magnetic resonance) to identify contributing factors like ion mobility, transport pathways, and active ion concentration. NMR reveals that increasing LLZO content generally decreases ion mobility, shifts transport pathways from PEO to an LLZO network, and increases active Li-ion concentration (despite some blockage).
*   **Electrochemical stability**: Despite not always leading to high ionic conductivity, high LLZO content significantly improves the stability of the composite electrolytes in solid-state batteries with Li metal anodes, extending their cycling life.
*   **Conclusions**: Ion conduction in composite electrolytes is complex, governed by active ion concentration, mobility, and transport pathways. Solid-state NMR is crucial for understanding these parameters and their interplay, revealing underlying reasons for conductivity changes, such as the unexpected contribution of Li from decomposed LLZO.

metadata.original_title: Discussion of Ionic Conductivity and Stability

nodes.title: Qualitative Evaluation of LLZO Impact on Ionic Conductivity
nodes.text:
conductivity. On the basis of the above analysis, the qualitative
evaluation of the impact of LLZO on ionic conductivity is asfollows: at low content of LLZO (e.g., 5 wt %), LLZO serves asaﬁller to reduce the crystallinity of PEO. Large LLZO particles
may also block the Li-ion pathways in PEO and reduce Li-ionmobility. Whether or not the ﬁllers at a certain concentration
enhance or reduce ionic conduction depends on the weighingof the two competing e ﬀects. In addition, if the ﬁller contains
Li, it may become an additional source of Li ions participatingin conduction. For instance, in LLZO (20 wt %) −PEO
(LiTFSI), Li from decomposed LLZO becomes one majorcharge carrier source, which is expected to enhance ionicconductivity. At high content of LLZO (e.g., 50 wt %), LLZO −
PEO (LiTFSI) becomes an LLZO ceramic conductor. This ispartially due to the formation of a percolated network of LLZO
particles to make ion conduction within the LLZO matrix
possible and partially due to the signi ﬁcant blockage of ion
channels in PEO. Therefore, the ionic conductivity is largelydetermined by loosely connected LLZO particles, of which theionic conductivity is on the order of 10
−6−10−7S/cm ( Figure
S5). With the addition of a liquid additive such as TEGDME,
the mobility of particles increases, which partially disintegratesthe LLZO network. This has two e ﬀects: (i) Li-ion pathway
through the LLZO network is largely broken, and the role ofLLZO in ion conduction is reduced; (ii) it reduces the blockageof Li-ion channels in PEO. In addition, TEGDME furtherreduces PEO crystallinity and enhances ion mobility within thePEO−TEGDME complex. As a result, LLZO (50 wt %) −PEO
(LiTFSI) (50 wt %) −TEGDME becomes predominantly a
polymer electrolyte modi ﬁed by a plasticizer.
The ionic conductivities of PEO and LLZO −PEO composite
electrolytes with various fractions of LLZO and TEGDME aredetermined by EIS, with the results shown in Figure 4 .
Compared with PEO (LiTFSI), LLZO (5 wt %) −PEO
(LiTFSI) showed a slight reduction in ionic conductivity.This suggests that blocking e ﬀect overweighs the bene ﬁts from
reduced polymer crystallinity. About 1.5-fold conductivityenhancement is observed in LLZO (20 wt %) −PEO (LiTFSI);
this is largely attributed to the increase in Li salt concentrationfrom the decomposed LLZO ( Figure 2 andTable 2 ). LLZO(50 wt %) −PEO (LiTFSI) shows notably lower ionic
conductivity compared to that of other composites. This isdue to the fact that LLZO particles almost completely block thepathways through PEO ( Figure 2 and Table 2 ), and the
alternative pathway through loosely connected LLZO particlesdoes not provide high ionic conductivity. A signi ﬁcant
enhancement in ionic conductivity is observed for LLZO (50wt %)−PEO (LiTFSI) (50 wt %) −TEGDME due to increased
ion mobility and re-established ion conduction channels withinTEGDME-modi ﬁed PEO.
The above discussion reveals various reasons accounting for
the observations of changes in the ionic conductivities ofcomposite electrolytes. Solid-state NMR is capable of clearlyidentifying the contributing factors, including ion mobility, iontransport pathways, and active ion concentration, and following
their changes. This helps pinpoint why certain strategies for
ionic conductivity enhancement fail and others work but forreasons other than apparent explanations. For instance, theobserved increase in ionic conductivity for LLZO (20 wt %) −
PEO (LiTFSI) is merely due to extra Li ions from decomposedLLZO, which has not been identi ﬁed and discussed before.
This may explain a number of observations in reported studiesthat large ionic conductivity was observed for Li-containingﬁllers compared to that for ﬁllers without Li.
21−27The results
also infer that composites with a large content of ceramicparticles in polymers are not likely to produce synergies forionic conductivity enhancement, as the polymer −ceramic
interfaces play a very small role in ion conduction.
Despite the fact that high content of LLZO does not lead to
high ionic conductivity, it increases the stability of thecomposite when used in solid-state batteries with Li metal asthe anode. Symmetric cells made of Li metal electrodes andPEO or composite electrolytes are cycled with a constantcurrent of 15 μA/cm
2, and the current direction is switched
every 60 min. The cell voltage pro ﬁle as a function of cycling
time is presented in Figure S6 . The cell voltage increases over
time for all electrolytes, indicating the increase of impedanceinduced by electrochemical instability. The voltage of PEOreached 10 V after 366 cycles. With the addition of LLZO, thestability improved signi ﬁcantly. LLZO (5 wt %) −PEO
(LiTFSI) was cycled for 743 times before arriving at 10 V,and LLZO (50 wt %) −PEO (LiTFSI) lasted for 920 cycles
before arriving at 5 V.
■CONCLUSIONS
Ion conduction within composite electrolytes is very complex.As in single-component ion conductors, active ion concen-tration, mobility, and transport pathways determine ionicconductivity. The variations of these three parameters and theirinterplay within the multiple phases of composite electrolytesfurther complicate the mechanism for ion conduction. Thestudy has employed solid-state NMR to determine ion mobility,ion transport pathways, and active concentration in LLZO −
PEO composite electrolytes and their compositional depend-ence. The results have revealed that with increasing LLZOcontent, ion mobility decreas es; ion transport pathways
gradually transition from PEO phase to percolated network
made of loosely connected LLZO particles; and the active Li-ion concentration increases in general but with certain loss dueto LLZO-blocked pathways in the polymer phase. Thecompositional dependence of these three parameters explainsthe observed ionic conductivity in this work and also sheds lighton many reported ionic conductivity measurements of
Figure 4. Conductivity of PEO (LiTFSI), LLZO (5 wt %) −PEO
(LiTFSI), LLZO (20 wt %) −PEO (LiTFSI), LLZO (50 wt %) −PEO
(LiTFSI), and LLZO (50 wt %) −PEO (LiTFSI) (50 wt %) −
TEGDME.ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces Research Article
DOI: 10.1021/acsami.7b17301
ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces 2018, 10, 4113 −41204118

channels in PEO. Therefore, the ionic conductivity is largelydetermined by loosely connected LLZO particles, of which theionic conductivity is on the order of 10
−6−10−7S/cm ( Figure
S5). With the addition of a liquid additive such as TEGDME,
the mobility of particles increases, which partially disintegratesthe LLZO network. This has two e ﬀects: (i) Li-ion pathway
through the LLZO network is largely broken, and the role ofLLZO in ion conduction is reduced; (ii) it reduces the blockageof Li-ion channels in PEO. In addition, TEGDME furtherreduces PEO crystallinity and enhances ion mobility within thePEO−TEGDME complex. As a result, LLZO (50 wt %) −PEO
(LiTFSI) (50 wt %) −TEGDME becomes predominantly a
polymer electrolyte modi ﬁed by a plasticizer.
The ionic conductivities of PEO and LLZO −PEO composite
electrolytes with various fractions of LLZO and TEGDME aredetermined by EIS, with the results shown in Figure 4 .
Compared with PEO (LiTFSI), LLZO (5 wt %) −PEO
(LiTFSI) showed a slight reduction in ionic conductivity.This suggests that blocking e ﬀect overweighs the bene ﬁts from
reduced polymer crystallinity. About 1.5-fold conductivityenhancement is observed in LLZO (20 wt %) −PEO (LiTFSI);
this is largely attributed to the increase in Li salt concentrationfrom the decomposed LLZO ( Figure 2 andTable 2 ). LLZO(50 wt %) −PEO (LiTFSI) shows notably lower ionic
conductivity compared to that of other composites. This isdue to the fact that LLZO particles almost completely block thepathways through PEO ( Figure 2 and Table 2 ), and the
alternative pathway through loosely connected LLZO particlesdoes not provide high ionic conductivity. A signi ﬁcant
enhancement in ionic conductivity is observed for LLZO (50wt %)−PEO (LiTFSI) (50 wt %) −TEGDME due to increased
ion mobility and re-established ion conduction channels withinTEGDME-modi ﬁed PEO.
The above discussion reveals various reasons accounting for
the observations of changes in the ionic conductivities ofcomposite electrolytes. Solid-state NMR is capable of clearlyidentifying the contributing factors, including ion mobility, iontransport pathways, and active ion concentration, and following
their changes. This helps pinpoint why certain strategies for
ionic conductivity enhancement fail and others work but forreasons other than apparent explanations. For instance, theobserved increase in ionic conductivity for LLZO (20 wt %) −
PEO (LiTFSI) is merely due to extra Li ions from decomposedLLZO, which has not been identi ﬁed and discussed before.
This may explain a number of observations in reported studiesthat large ionic conductivity was observed for Li-containingﬁllers compared to that for ﬁllers without Li.
21−27The results
also infer that composites with a large content of ceramicparticles in polymers are not likely to produce synergies forionic conductivity enhancement, as the polymer −ceramic
interfaces play a very small role in ion conduction.
Despite the fact that high content of LLZO does not lead to
high ionic conductivity, it increases the stability of thecomposite when used in solid-state batteries with Li metal asthe anode. Symmetric cells made of Li metal electrodes andPEO or composite electrolytes are cycled with a constantcurrent of 15 μA/cm
2, and the current direction is switched
every 60 min. The cell voltage pro ﬁle as a function of cycling
time is presented in Figure S6 . The cell voltage increases over
time for all electrolytes, indicating the increase of impedanceinduced by electrochemical instability. The voltage of PEOreached 10 V after 366 cycles. With the addition of LLZO, thestability improved signi ﬁcantly. LLZO (5 wt %) −PEO
(LiTFSI) was cycled for 743 times before arriving at 10 V,and LLZO (50 wt %) −PEO (LiTFSI) lasted for 920 cycles
before arriving at 5 V.
■CONCLUSIONS
Ion conduction within composite electrolytes is very complex.As in single-component ion conductors, active ion concen-tration, mobility, and transport pathways determine ionicconductivity. The variations of these three parameters and theirinterplay within the multiple phases of composite electrolytesfurther complicate the mechanism for ion conduction. Thestudy has employed solid-state NMR to determine ion mobility,ion transport pathways, and active concentration in LLZO −
PEO composite electrolytes and their compositional depend-ence. The results have revealed that with increasing LLZOcontent, ion mobility decreas es; ion transport pathways
gradually transition from PEO phase to percolated network
made of loosely connected LLZO particles; and the active Li-ion concentration increases in general but with certain loss dueto LLZO-blocked pathways in the polymer phase. Thecompositional dependence of these three parameters explainsthe observed ionic conductivity in this work and also sheds lighton many reported ionic conductivity measurements of

(LiTFSI), LLZO (20 wt %) −PEO (LiTFSI), LLZO (50 wt %) −PEO
(LiTFSI), and LLZO (50 wt %) −PEO (LiTFSI) (50 wt %) −

nodes.summary:
This partial document discusses the impact of varying concentrations of LLZO (lithium lanthanum zirconium oxide) and the addition of TEGDME (triethylene glycol dimethyl ether) on the ionic conductivity and stability of PEO (polyethylene oxide) composite electrolytes.

Key points covered include:
*   **Effect of LLZO content on ionic conductivity:**
    *   **Low LLZO (5 wt%)**: Acts as a filler, reducing PEO crystallinity but also blocking Li-ion pathways, resulting in a slight reduction in conductivity.
    *   **Medium LLZO (20 wt%)**: Shows enhanced conductivity, primarily attributed to additional Li ions released from decomposed LLZO, which act as charge carriers.
    *   **High LLZO (50 wt%)**: Leads to significantly lower ionic conductivity as LLZO particles block PEO pathways, and the conduction relies on a loosely connected LLZO network with inherently lower conductivity.
*   **Role of TEGDME additive**: For high LLZO content (50 wt%), adding TEGDME significantly enhances ionic conductivity by reducing PEO crystallinity, increasing ion mobility, and re-establishing ion conduction channels within the TEGDME-modified PEO, effectively transforming it into a plasticizer-modified polymer electrolyte.
*   **Analytical methods and insights**: EIS (Electrochemical Impedance Spectroscopy) was used for conductivity measurements. Solid-state NMR is highlighted as a crucial tool for identifying contributing factors like ion mobility, ion transport pathways, and active ion concentration, revealing that the observed conductivity enhancements are not always due to expected reasons (e.g., extra Li from decomposed LLZO).
*   **Stability improvement**: Despite not always leading to higher ionic conductivity, high LLZO content significantly improves the electrochemical stability of the composite electrolytes when used in solid-state batteries with Li metal anodes, as demonstrated by extended cycling performance.
*   **Overall conclusion**: Ion conduction in composite electrolytes is complex, governed by active ion concentration, mobility, and transport pathways, which are influenced by LLZO content and additives. The study provides a detailed qualitative and quantitative analysis of these interplays.

nodes.summary:
This partial document discusses the impact of varying concentrations of LLZO (lithium lanthanum zirconium oxide) and the addition of TEGDME (tetraethylene glycol dimethyl ether) on the ionic conductivity and stability of PEO (polyethylene oxide) composite electrolytes.

Key points covered include:
*   **Effect of LLZO concentration on ionic conductivity:**
    *   **Low LLZO (5 wt%)**: Acts as a filler, reducing PEO crystallinity but also blocking Li-ion pathways, leading to a slight reduction in conductivity.
    *   **Medium LLZO (20 wt%)**: Shows enhanced conductivity primarily due to additional Li ions released from decomposed LLZO, acting as a major charge carrier source.
    *   **High LLZO (50 wt%)**: Transforms the composite into an LLZO ceramic conductor with a percolated network, but also significantly blocks PEO pathways. This results in notably lower ionic conductivity due to the limited conduction through loosely connected LLZO particles.
*   **Role of TEGDME additive**: For high LLZO content (50 wt%), adding TEGDME significantly enhances ionic conductivity by increasing ion mobility, reducing PEO crystallinity, and re-establishing ion conduction channels within the PEO-TEGDME complex.
*   **Methodology and insights**: The study uses EIS (electrochemical impedance spectroscopy) to measure conductivity and solid-state NMR (nuclear magnetic resonance) to identify contributing factors like ion mobility, transport pathways, and active ion concentration. NMR reveals that increasing LLZO content generally decreases ion mobility, shifts transport pathways from PEO to an LLZO network, and increases active Li-ion concentration (despite some blockage).
*   **Electrochemical stability**: Despite not always leading to high ionic conductivity, high LLZO content significantly improves the stability of the composite electrolytes in solid-state batteries with Li metal anodes, extending their cycling life.
*   **Conclusions**: Ion conduction in composite electrolytes is complex, governed by active ion concentration, mobility, and transport pathways. Solid-state NMR is crucial for understanding these parameters and their interplay, revealing underlying reasons for conductivity changes, such as the unexpected contribution of Li from decomposed LLZO.

evaluation of the impact of LLZO on ionic conductivity is asfollows: at low content of LLZO (e.g., 5 wt %), LLZO serves asaﬁller to reduce the crystallinity of PEO. Large LLZO particles
may also block the Li-ion pathways in PEO and reduce Li-ionmobility. Whether or not the ﬁllers at a certain concentration
enhance or reduce ionic conduction depends on the weighingof the two competing e ﬀects. In addition, if the ﬁller contains
Li, it may become an additional source of Li ions participatingin conduction. For instance, in LLZO (20 wt %) −PEO
(LiTFSI), Li from decomposed LLZO becomes one majorcharge carrier source, which is expected to enhance ionicconductivity. At high content of LLZO (e.g., 50 wt %), LLZO −
PEO (LiTFSI) becomes an LLZO ceramic conductor. This ispartially due to the formation of a percolated network of LLZO
particles to make ion conduction within the LLZO matrix
possible and partially due to the signi ﬁcant blockage of ion
channels in PEO. Therefore, the ionic conductivity is largelydetermined by loosely connected LLZO particles, of which theionic conductivity is on the order of 10
−6−10−7S/cm ( Figure
S5). With the addition of a liquid additive such as TEGDME,
the mobility of particles increases, which partially disintegratesthe LLZO network. This has two e ﬀects: (i) Li-ion pathway
through the LLZO network is largely broken, and the role ofLLZO in ion conduction is reduced; (ii) it reduces the blockageof Li-ion channels in PEO. In addition, TEGDME furtherreduces PEO crystallinity and enhances ion mobility within thePEO−TEGDME complex. As a result, LLZO (50 wt %) −PEO
(LiTFSI) (50 wt %) −TEGDME becomes predominantly a
polymer electrolyte modi ﬁed by a plasticizer.
The ionic conductivities of PEO and LLZO −PEO composite
electrolytes with various fractions of LLZO and TEGDME aredetermined by EIS, with the results shown in Figure 4 .
Compared with PEO (LiTFSI), LLZO (5 wt %) −PEO
(LiTFSI) showed a slight reduction in ionic conductivity.This suggests that blocking e ﬀect overweighs the bene ﬁts from
reduced polymer crystallinity. About 1.5-fold conductivityenhancement is observed in LLZO (20 wt %) −PEO (LiTFSI);
this is largely attributed to the increase in Li salt concentrationfrom the decomposed LLZO ( Figure 2 andTable 2 ). LLZO(50 wt %) −PEO (LiTFSI) shows notably lower ionic
conductivity compared to that of other composites. This isdue to the fact that LLZO particles almost completely block thepathways through PEO ( Figure 2 and Table 2 ), and the
alternative pathway through loosely connected LLZO particlesdoes not provide high ionic conductivity. A signi ﬁcant
enhancement in ionic conductivity is observed for LLZO (50wt %)−PEO (LiTFSI) (50 wt %) −TEGDME due to increased
ion mobility and re-established ion conduction channels withinTEGDME-modi ﬁed PEO.
The above discussion reveals various reasons accounting for
the observations of changes in the ionic conductivities ofcomposite electrolytes. Solid-state NMR is capable of clearlyidentifying the contributing factors, including ion mobility, iontransport pathways, and active ion concentration, and following
their changes. This helps pinpoint why certain strategies for
ionic conductivity enhancement fail and others work but forreasons other than apparent explanations. For instance, theobserved increase in ionic conductivity for LLZO (20 wt %) −
PEO (LiTFSI) is merely due to extra Li ions from decomposedLLZO, which has not been identi ﬁed and discussed before.
This may explain a number of observations in reported studiesthat large ionic conductivity was observed for Li-containingﬁllers compared to that for ﬁllers without Li.
21−27The results
also infer that composites with a large content of ceramicparticles in polymers are not likely to produce synergies forionic conductivity enhancement, as the polymer −ceramic
interfaces play a very small role in ion conduction.
Despite the fact that high content of LLZO does not lead to
high ionic conductivity, it increases the stability of thecomposite when used in solid-state batteries with Li metal asthe anode. Symmetric cells made of Li metal electrodes andPEO or composite electrolytes are cycled with a constantcurrent of 15 μA/cm
2, and the current direction is switched
every 60 min. The cell voltage pro ﬁle as a function of cycling
time is presented in Figure S6 . The cell voltage increases over
time for all electrolytes, indicating the increase of impedanceinduced by electrochemical instability. The voltage of PEOreached 10 V after 366 cycles. With the addition of LLZO, thestability improved signi ﬁcantly. LLZO (5 wt %) −PEO
(LiTFSI) was cycled for 743 times before arriving at 10 V,and LLZO (50 wt %) −PEO (LiTFSI) lasted for 920 cycles
before arriving at 5 V.
■CONCLUSIONS
Ion conduction within composite electrolytes is very complex.As in single-component ion conductors, active ion concen-tration, mobility, and transport pathways determine ionicconductivity. The variations of these three parameters and theirinterplay within the multiple phases of composite electrolytesfurther complicate the mechanism for ion conduction. Thestudy has employed solid-state NMR to determine ion mobility,ion transport pathways, and active concentration in LLZO −
PEO composite electrolytes and their compositional depend-ence. The results have revealed that with increasing LLZOcontent, ion mobility decreas es; ion transport pathways
gradually transition from PEO phase to percolated network
made of loosely connected LLZO particles; and the active Li-ion concentration increases in general but with certain loss dueto LLZO-blocked pathways in the polymer phase. Thecompositional dependence of these three parameters explainsthe observed ionic conductivity in this work and also sheds lighton many reported ionic conductivity measurements of

(LiTFSI), LLZO (20 wt %) −PEO (LiTFSI), LLZO (50 wt %) −PEO
(LiTFSI), and LLZO (50 wt %) −PEO (LiTFSI) (50 wt %) −

nodes.summary:
This partial document discusses the impact of varying concentrations of LLZO (lithium lanthanum zirconium oxide) and the addition of TEGDME (triethylene glycol dimethyl ether) on the ionic conductivity and stability of PEO (polyethylene oxide) composite electrolytes.

Key points covered include:
*   **Effect of LLZO content on ionic conductivity:**
    *   **Low LLZO (5 wt%)**: Acts as a filler, reducing PEO crystallinity but also blocking Li-ion pathways, resulting in a slight reduction in conductivity.
    *   **Medium LLZO (20 wt%)**: Shows enhanced conductivity, primarily attributed to additional Li ions released from decomposed LLZO, which act as charge carriers.
    *   **High LLZO (50 wt%)**: Leads to significantly lower ionic conductivity as LLZO particles block PEO pathways, and the conduction relies on a loosely connected LLZO network with inherently lower conductivity.
*   **Role of TEGDME additive**: For high LLZO content (50 wt%), adding TEGDME significantly enhances ionic conductivity by reducing PEO crystallinity, increasing ion mobility, and re-establishing ion conduction channels within the TEGDME-modified PEO, effectively transforming it into a plasticizer-modified polymer electrolyte.
*   **Analytical methods and insights**: EIS (Electrochemical Impedance Spectroscopy) was used for conductivity measurements. Solid-state NMR is highlighted as a crucial tool for identifying contributing factors like ion mobility, ion transport pathways, and active ion concentration, revealing that the observed conductivity enhancements are not always due to expected reasons (e.g., extra Li from decomposed LLZO).
*   **Stability improvement**: Despite not always leading to higher ionic conductivity, high LLZO content significantly improves the electrochemical stability of the composite electrolytes when used in solid-state batteries with Li metal anodes, as demonstrated by extended cycling performance.
*   **Overall conclusion**: Ion conduction in composite electrolytes is complex, governed by active ion concentration, mobility, and transport pathways, which are influenced by LLZO content and additives. The study provides a detailed qualitative and quantitative analysis of these interplays.

metadata.original_title: Complexities of Ion Conduction in Composite Electrolytes

structure.summary:
This partial document describes a study on Li-ion transport in polymer-ceramic composite electrolytes, specifically focusing on poly(ethylene oxide) (PEO) and cubic-Li7La3Zr2O12 (LLZO) with lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)imide (LiTFSI).

The main points covered are:

1.  **Research Objective:** To identify Li-ion transport pathways, determine ion mobility, and quantify active Li concentration within these composite electrolytes, and to understand their relative effects on overall ionic conductivity.
2.  **Experimental Methods:**
    *   **Material Synthesis:** Cubic LLZO was synthesized using a sol-gel method.
    *   **Composite Film Preparation:** Films were prepared via a solution casting method, incorporating PEO, LiTFSI, and varying fractions of LLZO (5, 20, 50 wt%), with some samples including tetraethylene glycol dimethyl ether (TEGDME) as an additive.
    *   **Characterization Techniques:** Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was used to measure ionic conductivity, galvanostatic cycling for battery performance, and solid-state 6Li magic-angle spinning (MAS) NMR was employed as a primary tool to probe local structural environments, dynamics, and transport pathways.
3.  **Key Findings and Discussion:**
    *   **NMR Characterization:** Identified distinct Li environments in LLZO, PEO (LiTFSI), the LLZO-PEO interface, and decomposed LLZO (Li2CO3) formed during ball-milling. TEGDME was found to enhance LLZO breakdown and interface formation.
    *   **Li-ion Mobility:** 7Li T1 relaxation time measurements showed that increasing LLZO content generally decreases Li-ion mobility, likely due to increased rigidity and blockage of transport channels. The addition of TEGDME, however, increased Li-ion mobility.
    *   **Li-ion Transport Pathways:** Using a 6Li→7Li isotope replacement method, the study revealed a transition in dominant transport pathways:
        *   At low LLZO content (5 wt%), Li-ion transport primarily occurs through the PEO matrix.
        *   At medium LLZO content (20 wt%), Li-ion conduction occurs via Li salts in PEO, with a significant contribution from decomposed LLZO acting as an additional charge carrier source.
        *   At high LLZO content (50 wt%), the majority of Li ions transport through a percolated network formed by LLZO particles, with minor contributions from the PEO-LiTFSI phase.
        *   With TEGDME additive, Li-ion transport predominantly shifts back to the TEGDME-modified polymer phase.
    *   **Ionic Conductivity:**
        *   Low LLZO content (5 wt%) showed a slight reduction in conductivity due to blocking effects outweighing benefits from reduced polymer crystallinity.
        *   Medium LLZO content (20 wt%) resulted in a 1.5-fold conductivity enhancement, primarily attributed to increased active Li concentration from decomposed LLZO.
        *   High LLZO content (50 wt%) led to notably lower conductivity, as LLZO particles blocked PEO pathways, and the loosely connected LLZO network provided poor conduction.
        *   The addition of TEGDME significantly enhanced conductivity by increasing ion mobility and re-establishing conduction channels within the polymer phase.
    *   **Battery Stability:** Higher LLZO content was shown to improve the electrochemical stability of symmetric Li metal cells.
4.  **Conclusion:** The study highlights the complex interplay of ion mobility, transport pathways, and active ion concentration in composite electrolytes. Solid-state NMR proved crucial in dissecting these factors, explaining observed conductivity trends, and revealing previously unidentified contributions (e.g., from decomposed LLZO).

This may explain a number of observations in reported studiesthat large ionic conductivity was observed for Li-containingﬁllers compared to that for ﬁllers without Li.
21−27The results
also infer that composites with a large content of ceramicparticles in polymers are not likely to produce synergies forionic conductivity enhancement, as the polymer −ceramic
interfaces play a very small role in ion conduction.
Despite the fact that high content of LLZO does not lead to
high ionic conductivity, it increases the stability of thecomposite when used in solid-state batteries with Li metal asthe anode. Symmetric cells made of Li metal electrodes andPEO or composite electrolytes are cycled with a constantcurrent of 15 μA/cm
2, and the current direction is switched
every 60 min. The cell voltage pro ﬁle as a function of cycling
time is presented in Figure S6 . The cell voltage increases over
time for all electrolytes, indicating the increase of impedanceinduced by electrochemical instability. The voltage of PEOreached 10 V after 366 cycles. With the addition of LLZO, thestability improved signi ﬁcantly. LLZO (5 wt %) −PEO
(LiTFSI) was cycled for 743 times before arriving at 10 V,and LLZO (50 wt %) −PEO (LiTFSI) lasted for 920 cycles
before arriving at 5 V.
■CONCLUSIONS
Ion conduction within composite electrolytes is very complex.As in single-component ion conductors, active ion concen-tration, mobility, and transport pathways determine ionicconductivity. The variations of these three parameters and theirinterplay within the multiple phases of composite electrolytesfurther complicate the mechanism for ion conduction. Thestudy has employed solid-state NMR to determine ion mobility,ion transport pathways, and active concentration in LLZO −
PEO composite electrolytes and their compositional depend-ence. The results have revealed that with increasing LLZOcontent, ion mobility decreas es; ion transport pathways
gradually transition from PEO phase to percolated network
made of loosely connected LLZO particles; and the active Li-ion concentration increases in general but with certain loss dueto LLZO-blocked pathways in the polymer phase. Thecompositional dependence of these three parameters explainsthe observed ionic conductivity in this work and also sheds lighton many reported ionic conductivity measurements of
Figure 4. Conductivity of PEO (LiTFSI), LLZO (5 wt %) −PEO
(LiTFSI), LLZO (20 wt %) −PEO (LiTFSI), LLZO (50 wt %) −PEO
(LiTFSI), and LLZO (50 wt %) −PEO (LiTFSI) (50 wt %) −
TEGDME.ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces Research Article
DOI: 10.1021/acsami.7b17301
ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces 2018, 10, 4113 −41204118
composite electrolytes. In summary, this work demonstrates
that the complicated ion conduction in composite electrolytescan be understood and solid-state NMR is a particularly usefultool for determining the contributing factors for ionicconduction. The methodology and results from this work willfacilitate the development of high-performance compositeelectrolytes for rechargeable solid-state batteries.

structure.summary:
This partial document describes the complex mechanisms governing ionic conductivity in LLZO-PEO composite electrolytes, investigating the impact of varying LLZO content and the addition of a liquid additive (TEGDME).

Key points covered include:
*   **Effect of LLZO concentration on ionic conductivity:**
    *   **Low LLZO (5 wt%)** slightly reduces conductivity due to particle blocking outweighing reduced PEO crystallinity.
    *   **Medium LLZO (20 wt%)** enhances conductivity, primarily attributed to additional Li ions released from decomposed LLZO.
    *   **High LLZO (50 wt%)** results in lower conductivity, as LLZO particles block PEO pathways and the alternative conduction through loosely connected LLZO particles is inefficient.
*   **Role of TEGDME additive:** Adding TEGDME to high LLZO composites significantly enhances ionic conductivity by reducing PEO crystallinity, improving ion mobility, and re-establishing ion conduction channels within the PEO-TEGDME complex.
*   **Methodology and insights:** Solid-state NMR is highlighted as a crucial tool for identifying contributing factors like ion mobility, transport pathways, and active ion concentration, revealing that observed conductivity changes are often due to previously unacknowledged reasons (e.g., Li from decomposed LLZO).
*   **Electrochemical stability:** Despite not always leading to higher conductivity, high LLZO content significantly improves the electrochemical stability of the composite electrolytes in solid-state lithium metal batteries.
*   **Overall conclusion:** Ion conduction in composite electrolytes is complex, influenced by active ion concentration, mobility, and transport pathways. Solid-state NMR is a powerful technique for understanding these factors, which is vital for developing high-performance composite electrolytes.

nodes.summary: This partial document summarizes research on understanding ion conduction in composite electrolytes, particularly for rechargeable solid-state batteries. It highlights solid-state NMR as a crucial tool for identifying factors influencing ionic conduction and aims to facilitate the development of high-performance composite electrolytes. The document also includes details on associated supporting information (e.g., SEM, NMR, EIS data), author contact information, acknowledgments for funding, and a comprehensive list of references related to solid-state battery technology and various electrolyte materials.

nodes.summary: This partial document is the concluding section of a scientific paper. It summarizes the work's findings, emphasizing that ion conduction in composite electrolytes can be understood, and solid-state NMR is a valuable tool for identifying factors influencing ionic conduction. The research aims to facilitate the development of high-performance composite electrolytes for rechargeable solid-state batteries. The document also includes details about associated supporting information (such as FWHM, SEM images, various NMR data, EIS, and electrochemical stability tests), author contact information, acknowledgments of funding sources (NSF, Marion Milligan Mason Award, AAAS), and a comprehensive list of 31 references related to electrical energy storage, lithium-ion batteries, solid-state electrolytes, and composite polymer electrolytes.

nodes.summary: This partial document is the concluding section of a scientific paper. It summarizes the work's findings, emphasizing that ion conduction in composite electrolytes can be understood, and solid-state NMR is a valuable tool for identifying factors influencing ionic conduction. The research aims to facilitate the development of high-performance composite electrolytes for rechargeable solid-state batteries. The document also includes details about associated supporting information (such as FWHM, SEM images, various NMR data, EIS, and electrochemical stability tests), author contact information, acknowledgments of funding sources (NSF, Marion Milligan Mason Award, AAAS), and a comprehensive list of 31 references related to electrical energy storage, lithium-ion batteries, solid-state electrolytes, and composite polymer electrolytes.

composite electrolytes. In summary, this work demonstrates

nodes.summary: This partial document summarizes research on understanding ion conduction in composite electrolytes, particularly for rechargeable solid-state batteries. It highlights solid-state NMR as a crucial tool for identifying factors influencing ionic conduction and aims to facilitate the development of high-performance composite electrolytes. The document also includes details on associated supporting information (e.g., SEM, NMR, EIS data), author contact information, acknowledgments for funding, and a comprehensive list of references related to solid-state battery technology and various electrolyte materials.

structure.summary: This partial document summarizes research on understanding ion conduction in composite electrolytes, particularly for rechargeable solid-state batteries. It highlights solid-state NMR as a crucial tool for identifying factors influencing ionic conduction and aims to facilitate the development of high-performance composite electrolytes. The document also includes details on associated supporting information (e.g., SEM, NMR, EIS data), author contact information, acknowledgments for funding, and a comprehensive list of references related to solid-state battery technology and various electrolyte materials.

structure.title: ■ACKNOWLEDGMENTS
structure.text:
composite electrolytes. In summary, this work demonstrates
that the complicated ion conduction in composite electrolytescan be understood and solid-state NMR is a particularly usefultool for determining the contributing factors for ionicconduction. The methodology and results from this work willfacilitate the development of high-performance compositeelectrolytes for rechargeable solid-state batteries.

nodes.title: Summary of Findings and Implications
nodes.text:
composite electrolytes. In summary, this work demonstrates

that the complicated ion conduction in composite electrolytescan be understood and solid-state NMR is a particularly usefultool for determining the contributing factors for ionicconduction. The methodology and results from this work willfacilitate the development of high-performance compositeelectrolytes for rechargeable solid-state batteries.
nodes.summary: This partial document is the concluding section of a scientific paper. It summarizes the work's findings, emphasizing that ion conduction in composite electrolytes can be understood, and solid-state NMR is a valuable tool for identifying factors influencing ionic conduction. The research aims to facilitate the development of high-performance composite electrolytes for rechargeable solid-state batteries. The document also includes details about associated supporting information (such as FWHM, SEM images, various NMR data, EIS, and electrochemical stability tests), author contact information, acknowledgments of funding sources (NSF, Marion Milligan Mason Award, AAAS), and a comprehensive list of 31 references related to electrical energy storage, lithium-ion batteries, solid-state electrolytes, and composite polymer electrolytes.

The document also includes details on associated supporting information (e.g., SEM, NMR, EIS data), author contact information, acknowledgments for funding, and a comprehensive list of references related to solid-state battery technology and various electrolyte materials.

structure.title: ■REFERENCES
structure.text:
composite electrolytes. In summary, this work demonstrates
that the complicated ion conduction in composite electrolytescan be understood and solid-state NMR is a particularly usefultool for determining the contributing factors for ionicconduction. The methodology and results from this work willfacilitate the development of high-performance compositeelectrolytes for rechargeable solid-state batteries.

structure.summary: This partial document summarizes research on composite electrolytes for rechargeable solid-state batteries, highlighting that ion conduction in these materials can be understood through the use of solid-state NMR as a key tool. The work aims to facilitate the development of high-performance composite electrolytes. It also details associated supporting information (e.g., NMR, SEM, EIS data), author contact information, acknowledgments of funding, and a comprehensive list of references related to solid-state batteries, various electrolyte types, and analytical methods.
